Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds George Max Anderson of the University of Louisville to conduct a research project, entitled "Investigation of nanometer-scale silicon carbon based particles to decrease size and increase performance of electronic devices," during the summer of 2012 at Shanghai University in Shanghai, China. The host scientist is Dr. Zihua Xin.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project lies in detecting minute differences in nano-scale objects that can result in significant property changes. By analyzing and learning what factors control these property changes, this research promises to exploit these differences to further efforts to miniaturize a wide range of electronic devices.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

 

The purpose of this project was to gain insight into the electronic and structural properties of nano-sized particles in hopes of utilizing these particles to decrease size and increase performance of electronic devices. Our focus was upon fullerene structures, which are nano-particles composed of carbon atoms arranged in a structure that forms an enclosed shape that has a hollow cavity in its center. In addition to the intellectual pursuit of this research, cultural impact was achieved by sharing of ideas and first hand interaction with people of different backgrounds through mutual seminars, collaboratory research, and social interaction. The above exchange has lead to future planed joint research between American and Chinese scientist, which may lead to improved relationships in the scientific community.

Results of this research has provided detailed information about how structural features of nano-particles contribute to electronic effects. Slight changes in fullerene shape can enhance or impair its ability to conduct electricity. For fullerenes that are composed of the same number of atoms, one can alter or select specific properties such as symmetry and size to fine tune electrical properties. The above feature may have applications in enhancing or altering the properties of devices composed of such particles.
